title: Telegram CEO Pavel Durov formally charged in France, prohibited from leaving the country
summary: Durov was charged with a number of violations related to the messaging app, but was granted conditional release against a bail of €5 million. He must also report to a police station twice a week and must remain in France.

title: Paris kicks off Paralympics with ceremony in heart of city
summary: Wednesday's opening ceremony was the first Paralympics ceremony not in a stadium – instead taking place in the Place de la Concorde, with 4,400 athletes parading down the Champs-Elysées.

title: Macron to visit Serbia, expected to announce fighter jets sale
summary: The French president should go to the Balkan country on Thursday and Friday, where he may announce a deal on a contract to sell 12 Rafales to Belgrade, which is known to have close ties with Moscow.

title: What would an impeachment procedure against Macron consist of?
summary: The lengthy mechanism provided for in Article 68 of the Constitution currently has virtually no chance of leading to the removal of the French president from office.

title: In Kyiv, Zelensky presents Ukrainian offensive in Kursk as 'victory plan'
summary: In a rare appearance before the press, the Ukrainian president, in a position of strength, justified the incursion of his armed forces into Russian territory in order to push Moscow to negotiate.

title: Northern India's discriminatory order against Muslim restaurant owners illustrates nationalist drift
summary: On the occasion of the Kanwar Yatra Hindu pilgrimage, officials in the state of Uttar Pradesh told Muslim restaurant owners to display their names to 'protect' pilgrims.

title: Why the Paralympics' TikTok account is causing controversy
summary: The account, where humorous videos about athletes are posted regularly, has 4.5 million followers and over 1 billion views.

title: Israel launches major military operation in West Bank
summary: The Israeli army said it had killed nine Palestinian 'terrorists' in its ongoing operation. The UN said the raids risked worsening an 'already catastrophic' situation.

title: Did Macron have to name a left-wing prime minister? No, but he could have, constitutional expert says
summary: The French president cited 'institutional stability' to justify his decision not to name Lucie Castets. The argument is more political than a 'legal constraint,' Benjamin Morel tells Le Monde in an interview.

title: US aid is still vital to Afghanistan
summary: Since the withdrawal of its troops from Kabul in the summer of 2021, the US has spent almost $21 billion on aid for Afghanistan. Part of this sum has kept the Taliban regime afloat.

title: Burkina Faso civilians pay ruling junta's anti-jihadist strategy with their lives
summary: Several hundred civilians were killed by jihadists on August 24 in Barsalogho, while digging trenches they had been told by the military regime would protect them.

title: Subtle, satisfying and cheap: Ramen is a slurpable phenomenon
summary: 'Influential Japanese cuisine' (3/6). This simmering emblem of Japanese gastronomy has spread far beyond its borders. Now, with heads over their bowls, everyone slurps and says 'ramen' in all its forms, even in the land of the pot-roast chicken!

title: US announces sanctions on Israeli settlers carrying out violence against Palestinians
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on Israeli settlers in the West Bank who have been setting up roadblocks, forcing Palestinians to leave their homes and attacking them.

title: Fears of stronger crackdown grow in Venezuela after Maduro appoints loyalist as interior minister
summary: The hardliner has long been considered the second most powerful person in the country. Rights groups fear it will worsen the government's heavy handed response to protests.

title: UK and Germany plan new treaty as part of post-Brexit 'reset'
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer and his German counterpart Olaf Scholz agreed on plans for a bilateral treaty, as well as discussing aid for Ukraine and how to crack down on migrant smuggling.

title: First rioter to enter US Capitol on January 6 sentenced to 53 months in prison
summary: In their sentencing memorandum, prosecutors said Michael Sparks, 46, 'helped light the fire that day.'

title: Paris 2024: Why China wins every Paralympic Games
summary: From spotting future talent to creating the world's largest training center for disabled athletes, China has created an effective system to ensure the country's success at the Olympics.

summary: 'Trump fictions' (1/6). In this series, Le Monde looks back at the movies and pop culture references that have fed the imagination of the former US president, who's again running for office this year.

title: Telegram CEO Pavel Durov charged but released under judicial supervision
summary: The cofounder of the messaging platform was arrested on Saturday evening at Le Bourget airport, a month and a half after the start of a judicial investigation into 12 charges, most of them relating to organized crime. He has been banned from leaving France.

title: Two suspects charged after France synagogue attack
summary: The main suspect is accused of attempted terrorist murder. He was not known to police.

title: Shein enlists the lobbying services of a former European commissioner to protect its business model in the EU
summary: The German Günther Oettinger will defend the interests of the Chinese group, which is trying to avoid new regulations on 'ultra-fast fashion' that could hamper its business.

title: High-level US official's visit to Beijing shows renewed dialogue between the two countries
summary: US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan has built a channel of communication with China's top diplomat, Wang Yi, over the past 15 months.

title: The 19th-century president the French left wishes Macron would take after
summary: Patrice de MacMahon was a president who bet on dissolution but failed, resisted and eventually relinquished power to the left. Sound familiar?

title: In the occupied West Bank, Israel accelerates settlement in a UNESCO-listed area
summary: Bezalel Smotrich, Israel's finance minister and a figure of the far-right supremacist movement, has announced his intention to 'initiate procedures for the establishment' of a new settlement on the outskirts of the ancient village of Battir.

title: Lucky Love: 'I'm familiar with rejection. I'm not afraid of it. I'm an artist. I sing.'
summary: During the opening ceremony of the Paralympic Games, the French artist, born without a left arm and a figure of Parisian LGBT nightlife, reinterpreted his famous track 'Masculinity,' a melancholy pop ballad about gender and body norms that has become 'My Ability.'

title: Powerful typhoon makes landfall in Japan, triggering flooding, tornadoes, and landslides
summary: Southern parts of the country saw wind gusts of up to 252 kilometers per hour, with authorities issuing evacuation warnings to hundreds of thousands of people.

summary: With their history, logos and the sports represented, these two international sporting events are not entirely similar.

summary: The 17th Summer Paralympic Games officially started on Wednesday on the Champs-Elysées and Place de la Concorde, in front of thousands of spectators.

title: In pictures: Ukrainians in Sumy torn between exaltation and anxiety
summary: Applauded in the early days, Kyiv's offensive in the Russian region of Kursk has also become a source of anguish for the Ukrainian border population. Le Monde photographer Adrien Vautier followed soldiers and civilians in this unexpected stage of the war.

title: Fewer teenagers are using condoms
summary: A third of 15 year olds say they did not use a condom or contraceptive pill the last time they had sex, according to a report published Thursday by the World Health Organization.

title: Suspect in attack on French synagogue charged with terrorism
summary: The National Anti-Terrorism Prosecutor's Office is handling a case of anti-Semitism for the first time since October 7, 2023. The alleged attacker has been charged with terrorist conspiracy and placed in custody.

title: Wife of French gendarme killed by driver who refused to comply says 'France killed my husband'
summary: The 39-year-old man had already been convicted 10 times, including for traffic offenses, and was placed under investigation on Wednesday.

title: Australia scraps plans to include gender and sexual orientation questions in census
summary: The country's center-left government's decision to abandon tentative plans to include questions about sexual and gender identity in the 2026 survey has prompted warnings that LGTBQ citizens may boycott the count.

title: Biden 'looking forward' to talks with China's Xi in coming weeks
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with US national security adviser Jake Sullivan on Thursday in Beijing in an effort to improve ties.

title: Foreign press hails Paris Paralympics opening ceremony
summary: Spared from controversy and rain, the Paralympic Games' opening ceremony and its message of unity captivated the press, without matching the extravagance of the Olympics.

title: Israel carries out large-scale raids in West Bank
summary: Three towns in the north of the occupied territory were targeted in a vast operation in which Israel announced it had eliminated nine 'terrorists.'

title: Five athletes lit the Paris Paralympics cauldron
summary: The two flag bearers, Nantenin Keïta and Alexis Hanquinquant, were joined by athlete Charles-Antoine Kouakou, swimmer Elodie Lorandi and table tennis player Fabien Lamirault at the opening ceremony on Wednesday night.

title: Why are there no athletes with Down's syndrome at the 2024 Paris Paralympics?
summary: The Paralympic Games's classification system includes only one class for athletes with an intellectual disability. People with Down's syndrome have virtually no chance of qualifying, as their performances are inferior to those of other adapted para-athletes.

title: Rescue of refugee baby moves Greece
summary: Images of a 50-day-old infant rescued on the small Greek island of Tilos have made the rounds of social media, which have hailed the islanders' 'humanity.'

title: Paralympics: What are the rules of 'murder ball,' or wheelchair rugby?
summary: Invented in 1977, the sport is a mixture of wheelchair basketball, field hockey and American football. Athletes will compete from August 29 to September 2 at the Paris Paralympic Games.

title: 'Kamala Harris takes a different view of the world and America's place in it'
summary: The US expert believes the vice president's foreign policy, should she reach the Oval Office, might be a surprise. While she's heir to the Democratic Party's traditional leadership, she's also sensitive to progressives' demands.

title: Paralympics: Ugo Didier, France's other super-gifted swimmer made in Toulouse
summary: A double silver and bronze medalist at the Tokyo Games, Didier dreams of emulating Léon Marchand in Paris. He won gold on Thursday in the 400-meter freestyle.

title: Paralympics: Changing the way we look at disability
summary: Transport, schooling, discrimination in hiring... The everyday problems encountered by disabled people are plentiful. The Paris Games should help raise awareness of the need to quickly rectify them.

title: How Telegram let pedophilia content flourish
summary: Pavel Durov's social media is the only major platform that doesn't take part in international programs run by NGOs to combat child pornography.

title: Israel agrees to 'humanitarian pauses' in Gaza for polio vaccinations
summary: The series of three-day pauses will allow UN health officials to administer vaccinations in the territory. The first case of the infectious disease in 25 years was confirmed this month in an unvaccinated 10-month-old baby.

title: How the Paralympics categorize disability to make it fair between athletes
summary: In parasports, each athlete competes under a code that indicates their disability. Medical and sports professionals try to put athletes of similar ability in the same events to make the sporting competition fair − but it's still not an exact science.

summary: The widely anticipated deal will see Serbia receive nine single-seat and three two-seat jets by 2029 for an undisclosed sum.

title: Macron defends move to give Telegram's Pavel Durov a French passport
summary: Speaking to reporters during a visit to Serbia on Thursday, the French president said he did not know that Durov would be coming to France.

title: Harris rejects 'flip-flop' claims in first campaign interview
summary: Republicans have criticized Kamala Harris for waiting until nearly six weeks after President Joe Biden dropped out of the White House race to give her first interview. Speaking with CNN on Thursday alongside her running mate Tim Walz, Harris said her 'values had not changed' on key issues.

title: Japan's rice shortage: the result of global warming and overtourism
summary: In anticipation of a 2024 harvest deemed encouraging by the government, several retailers have limited purchases to one packet of rice per family. The powerful typhoon Shansha – which hit Kyushu on Wednesday, August 28 – could further exacerbate the situation.

title: The Paris Paralympics, another battleground for two Ukrainian soldiers
summary: For the duration of the Paris Games, Major Dmytro Melnyk and veteran Yevhenii Korinets are serving their country far from the noise of war, as members of the national sitting volleyball team. They play their first match against Iran on August 30.
